title: Ryanair, EasyJet, Aer Lingus, Wizz Air, SAS, Air France, British Airways - Travel And Tour World
description:
In sum, the aviation industry is undergoing a transformation, driven by the sustainable practices of airlines such as Ryanair, EasyJet, Aer Lingus, Wizz Air, SAS, United Airlines, Air France, and British Airways.
How Ryanair, EasyJet, Aer Lingus, Wizz Air, SAS, United Airlines, Air France, and British Airways are Boosting the Airline Industry with Sustainable Development Sustainability has become a driving force in the airline industry, with environmental concerns gaining more attention than ever before.
In recent years, airlines such as Ryanair, EasyJet, Aer Lingus, Wizz Air, SAS, United Airlines, Air France, and British Airways have been at the forefront of integrating sustainable practices into their operations.
Ryanair, EasyJet, Aer Lingus, Wizz Air, SAS, United Airlines, Air France, and British Airways are all playing critical roles in boosting the airline industry’s commitment to sustainability.
What’s More in Travel And Tour World Read Travel Industry News in 104 different regional language platforms Get daily dose of news from Travel Industry, by subscribing to Travel And Tour World newsletters.
text:
Leading airlines such as Ryanair, EasyJet, Aer Lingus, Wizz Air, SAS, United Airlines, Air France, and British Airways are playing a crucial role in this shift, adopting innovative solutions that aim to create a greener future for the aviation industry. The European travel and airline industry-—tourism sector and aviation industry in Spain, France, Italy, Germany, Denmark, Finland and the Netherlands—is experiencing a period of significant change, influenced by policy reforms, shifting consumer preferences, and technological innovations. These developments in aviation industry are reshaping the landscape of tourism and transportation across the continent.​

Sustainability has emerged as a powerful catalyst for change in the airline industry, with increasing pressure from both consumers and regulators to reduce the environmental impact of air travel. The airline industry, known for its significant carbon footprint, is now embracing more sustainable practices to mitigate the effects of aviation on the planet.

These airlines are committed to reducing emissions and improving fuel efficiency, particularly through the modernization of their fleets. Ryanair and EasyJet, for example, are both focusing on integrating more fuel-efficient aircraft, which significantly reduce CO2 emissions. In addition, Aer Lingus and Wizz Air have been investing in sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), an alternative that is crucial for lowering the airline industry’s carbon footprint.

Airlines like SAS and United Airlines are also making strides by focusing on new technologies that reduce fuel consumption and operating costs. Air France and British Airways, two major international players, are spearheading efforts to integrate SAF into their operations and are also working on offset programs to balance their emissions.

In sum, the aviation industry is undergoing a transformation, driven by the sustainable practices of airlines such as Ryanair, EasyJet, Aer Lingus, Wizz Air, SAS, United Airlines, Air France, and British Airways. These airlines are not just leading the way in reducing their carbon footprints, but are helping the entire airline industry embrace a more sustainable and eco-friendly future.

UK’s Implementation of Electronic Travel Authorization (ETA)

Starting April 2, 2025, the United Kingdom introduced a significant policy change by extending its Electronic Travel Authorization (ETA) requirement to nationals of European Union (EU) member states, the European Economic Area (EEA), and Switzerland. This policy was initially aimed at travelers from countries outside the EU and has now been expanded to include European citizens, reflecting the UK’s growing focus on border security and immigration management post-Brexit. The ETA application involves travelers submitting personal and biometric data, including passport information and digital photographs. It has a processing fee of £10, which will rise to £16 on April 9, 2025. This new process aims to pre-screen travelers before they enter the UK, helping authorities identify potential security risks and illegal immigration attempts before arrival.

The ETA is valid for two years and allows multiple visits to the UK, with each stay limited to six months. This is a crucial change, especially for frequent travelers and business professionals who frequently visit the UK. However, Irish citizens are exempt from this new rule due to the Common Travel Area arrangement between Ireland and the UK. While the ETA system aims to streamline the entry process, it is expected to be met with some resistance from travelers who may find it an additional hurdle, particularly given the already complex travel documentation processes within Europe. Travelers must adjust to the new norms, making it essential for both leisure and business travelers to remain aware of these requirements.

Ryanair’s Route Adjustments Amid Tax Increases

Ryanair, one of Europe’s largest low-cost carriers, has made notable route adjustments in response to increased taxation and low demand for certain services. The airline announced a reduction of flights to French airports by up to 5%, a move that has caught the attention of many in the travel industry. Ryanair has already suspended flights from Paris-Vatry and Bordeaux airports, and further cuts are being considered for the winter 2025-26 season and the spring/summer 2026 period. This strategic shift comes as a response to rising taxes imposed on the aviation industry in France, which could lead to increased ticket prices. Such hikes are a significant concern for low-cost carriers like Ryanair, whose business model relies on keeping fares as low as possible to maintain competitiveness.

The decision to cut routes to French airports is seen as a direct reaction to the growing tax burden on the airline industry, which has been exacerbated by local government policies in France. These policies include environmental taxes and airport-specific charges, which ultimately affect the airline’s ability to keep fares affordable for passengers. Ryanair’s business model thrives on providing no-frills services at competitive prices, but the increasing tax burden could undermine this model if it leads to higher operational costs. This adjustment could also influence future route planning and the airline’s ability to maintain its presence in the European market, especially in countries with higher operational costs. As the situation develops, it will be interesting to see whether Ryanair continues to adjust its network to cope with these financial pressures or if it seeks other strategies to maintain profitability.

Expansion Plans at Athens International Airport

Athens International Airport is embarking on an ambitious £540 million expansion project, aimed at accommodating the growing number of travelers flocking to the city. The project is part of Greece’s broader effort to bolster its tourism infrastructure and cater to the ever-increasing demand for air travel, particularly as the Athens Riviera becomes an increasingly popular destination for both domestic and international tourists. The planned expansion will enhance the airport’s annual passenger capacity, increasing it from 26 million to 40 million by 2032. This project will involve a series of upgrades to the existing infrastructure, including the development of a larger terminal, additional lounges, and retail outlets, as well as an expanded Extra-Schengen area to handle the influx of international travelers.

The significance of this expansion is twofold: it will not only accommodate the growing number of passengers but also improve the overall travel experience by providing additional amenities and services to passengers. With Greece’s tourism sector recovering and even thriving post-pandemic, Athens has seen a steady increase in international arrivals, particularly from North America and other parts of Europe. Additionally, the airport’s strategic location as a hub for travelers heading to the Greek islands and the rest of Southeast Europe positions it as a crucial part of the region’s transportation network. This expansion reflects the increasing importance of Athens as a global tourist destination, bolstered by investments such as the development of luxury hotels along the Athens Riviera. As tourism continues to grow, this expansion will help Athens maintain its position as a top destination for global travelers.

Emerging Competition in High-Speed Rail Services

The high-speed rail sector in Europe is undergoing a transformation, with new competition emerging, especially in the vital London-Paris route. Companies such as Virgin, Evolyn, and Gemini are planning to operate services through the Channel Tunnel, which has traditionally been dominated by Eurostar. Virgin’s plans to invest up to £1 billion to launch a new transatlantic route will add an exciting new dimension to the rail market, potentially revolutionizing the way travelers move between major European cities. Evolyn, on the other hand, is working towards launching non-stop high-speed services between London and Paris by 2025, challenging the existing dominance of Eurostar on this route.

The entrance of these new players is expected to offer more choices for consumers and could lead to reduced prices due to increased competition. Virgin’s transatlantic service, which would run through the Channel Tunnel, is particularly noteworthy, as it represents a significant investment in high-speed rail as an alternative to air travel. This new competition may prompt other operators to adjust their pricing and service offerings to remain competitive. Moreover, the rise of high-speed rail as an alternative to air travel is also supported by growing concerns over environmental sustainability. Rail travel is significantly more eco-friendly than flying, which aligns with the increasing consumer preference for sustainable travel options. As more passengers opt for rail, particularly on short-to-medium haul routes, this shift is likely to continue reshaping the European transportation landscape.

The European airline industry is witnessing an exciting period of expansion and innovation, with several new routes being launched across both the short-haul and long-haul markets. This strategic growth reflects airlines’ ability to adapt to consumer demand, changing travel patterns, and economic conditions. The following highlights some of the most notable new routes, along with insights into their potential impacts on the industry.

New Airline Routes: Short-Haul Market Developments

The short-haul sector is highly competitive in Europe, with many airlines launching new routes to cater to the increasing demand for affordable and flexible travel options. Among the most significant additions in this segment are the following:

Ryanair, a leading European low-cost carrier, has introduced a twice-weekly service between Glasgow, Scotland, and Malta, which began in April 2025. This route not only connects two popular holiday destinations but also caters to both leisure and business travelers. Malta’s historic attractions, warm weather, and vibrant culture make it an appealing destination for travelers from Scotland, while the frequency of the route allows for both weekend and mid-week trips. This expansion is part of Ryanair’s broader plan to enhance its presence in key Mediterranean destinations.

EasyJet, another major player in the low-cost market, has launched a daily service between Edinburgh, Scotland, and Milan Linate, Italy. The new route, which commenced on March 30, 2025, offers travelers more frequent options to reach Milan, one of Europe’s fashion capitals. This move reflects EasyJet’s continued efforts to strengthen its connectivity between major European cities, catering to both leisure tourists and business professionals. Milan’s strong appeal in fashion, design, and food makes it a sought-after destination for short-haul travelers.

Aer Lingus, Ireland’s flagship airline, has introduced new routes from Cork, a city that has increasingly become a gateway for tourists to explore the west of Ireland. Starting on April 16, 2025, Aer Lingus will begin thrice-weekly services from Cork to Bilbao, Spain, and to Bordeaux, France, beginning in May. These routes reflect the airline’s strategy to tap into cultural and gastronomic tourism, as both Bilbao and Bordeaux are renowned for their wine production, culinary scenes, and rich histories. These destinations are poised to attract both leisure travelers and those seeking to explore Europe’s famed wine regions.

Wizz Air, a Hungarian low-cost carrier, has launched several new routes from Hamburg, Germany. Notable additions include flights to Sibiu (Romania), Kutaissi (Georgia), and Zagreb (Croatia). These routes, starting in the summer of 2025, provide access to less-visited destinations in Eastern and Southern Europe. Sibiu, in particular, is an attractive option for tourists seeking a quaint, medieval town with a mix of cultural events and local traditions. Kutaissi and Zagreb also offer unique experiences in Georgia and Croatia, further diversifying Europe’s travel landscape.

These new short-haul routes are not just a reflection of airlines’ efforts to expand their networks but also a response to shifting consumer preferences. Travelers are increasingly looking for affordable, direct options to both well-known and emerging destinations within Europe. By offering more frequency, better connectivity, and convenient travel times, airlines like Ryanair, EasyJet, Aer Lingus, and Wizz Air are poised to capitalize on this demand and strengthen their market positions.

Long-Haul Market Developments

While short-haul flights continue to dominate Europe’s airline industry, the long-haul market is also experiencing notable growth, with new routes being introduced to key international destinations. These expansions are particularly important as airlines seek to rebuild international travel volumes following disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Among the most prominent new long-haul routes are:

SAS (Scandinavian Airlines) has unveiled new flights from Oslo, Norway, to New York’s John F. Kennedy Airport (JFK) starting on March 30, 2025. This weekly route offers passengers from Norway and neighboring countries direct access to one of the world’s most iconic cities. SAS has also launched a new weekly service from Copenhagen, Denmark, to Tokyo Narita in Japan starting on April 1, 2025. These routes signify SAS’s commitment to providing high-quality long-haul services that connect Scandinavia with important global business and leisure hubs. Tokyo and New York are major destinations for both tourists and business professionals, making these additions strategically significant.

United Airlines, one of the largest U.S. carriers, has expanded its European footprint by introducing a historic direct flight from Newark, New Jersey, to Nuuk, Greenland, starting on June 14, 2025. This new service is particularly notable as it marks the first-ever commercial flight from the U.S. to Greenland, opening up a previously underserved market for American and European travelers seeking adventure and unique landscapes. Additionally, United is launching flights from Washington D.C. (IAD) to Dakar, Senegal, and from Washington D.C. to Venice, Italy, both in mid-2025. These routes will offer travelers more options to reach some of the most culturally rich destinations in Africa and Europe, supporting tourism and business exchange.

Air France and other major European carriers have also expanded their reach to key destinations in Asia and North America. For instance, Air France has introduced several new flights to cities like Tokyo and Seoul, while British Airways has added services to Miami and Vancouver. These routes reflect a broader trend of transatlantic and intercontinental connectivity, providing more choices for travelers heading to global hubs.

Strategic Implications

The introduction of these new routes reflects airlines’ strategies to meet the increasing demand for both short-haul and long-haul travel. As European cities continue to recover from the impacts of the pandemic, the new routes are designed to stimulate tourism and business travel while offering competitive pricing and convenient travel times.

Market Expansion: Airlines are focusing on underserved markets and niche destinations to diversify their networks. This includes routes to Greenland, smaller cities in Eastern Europe, and secondary cities in Western Europe. By tapping into these markets, airlines can cater to a broader range of travelers and attract more passengers.

Tourism Promotion: Many of the new routes are aimed at boosting tourism in destinations with significant cultural, historical, and gastronomic appeal. Cities like Bordeaux, Bilbao, and Zagreb are expected to see an increase in visitors, driving local economies and encouraging international tourism.

Enhanced Connectivity: New long-haul routes further enhance Europe’s global connectivity, making it easier for travelers to access business hubs like New York and Tokyo. This is crucial for strengthening Europe’s position in the global travel market, especially as the industry continues to recover.

How Ryanair, EasyJet, Aer Lingus, Wizz Air, SAS, United Airlines, Air France, and British Airways are Boosting the Airline Industry with Sustainable Development

Sustainability has become a driving force in the airline industry, with environmental concerns gaining more attention than ever before. In recent years, airlines such as Ryanair, EasyJet, Aer Lingus, Wizz Air, SAS, United Airlines, Air France, and British Airways have been at the forefront of integrating sustainable practices into their operations. These airlines are not only striving to minimize their carbon footprints but are also leading the charge to make air travel more eco-friendly, with strategies that range from fleet modernization to fuel efficiency improvements, carbon offset programs, and the adoption of alternative energy sources.

In this article, we will explore how these leading airlines are making strides in sustainability and how their efforts are boosting the airline industry.

Ryanair: A Low-Cost Leader in Sustainable Aviation

Ryanair, Europe’s largest low-cost carrier, has long been a pioneer in cost-effective and efficient flying. The airline is also making significant strides in sustainability. One of Ryanair’s most notable initiatives is its commitment to reducing its carbon footprint by introducing the most fuel-efficient aircraft in its fleet. Ryanair operates an all-Boeing 737 fleet, which has been upgraded with the latest fuel-saving technologies, significantly reducing its CO2 emissions per passenger.

In addition to fleet modernization, Ryanair has committed to achieving a 10% reduction in its carbon emissions per passenger by 2030. The airline has also been actively exploring the use of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) and aims to power 12.5% of its flights with SAF by 2030. By investing in these technologies and setting ambitious environmental targets, Ryanair is positioning itself as a leader in sustainable aviation while maintaining its low-cost model.

EasyJet: Leading the Way with Carbon Offset Programs

EasyJet, one of Europe’s leading low-cost carriers, has been a trailblazer in sustainable aviation. The airline has committed to reducing its net carbon emissions to zero by 2050, with a focus on advancing its carbon offset program and integrating more sustainable technologies into its operations.

One of EasyJet’s key sustainability initiatives is its carbon offset program, which allows passengers to offset the carbon emissions of their flights by investing in environmental projects, such as reforestation and renewable energy. EasyJet also works with its partners to promote the use of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF). In addition, EasyJet has been actively involved in exploring hybrid and electric aircraft, with the goal of reducing reliance on fossil fuels in the future.

The airline’s sustainable approach has made it a key player in the European aviation market, showing that sustainability and low-cost operations can go hand in hand. EasyJet’s focus on innovation and environmental responsibility has set an example for other low-cost carriers to follow.

Aer Lingus: A Step Towards Sustainable Aviation with New Aircraft

Aer Lingus, Ireland’s national carrier, has made significant progress in adopting sustainability practices. The airline’s strategy focuses on reducing its environmental impact through fleet modernization, fuel efficiency, and the use of sustainable aviation fuel.

Aer Lingus has been investing in newer, more fuel-efficient aircraft such as the Airbus A320neo family, which reduces fuel consumption and CO2 emissions by up to 20% compared to older models. The airline also prioritizes the use of SAF, with plans to increase its use of sustainable fuels as part of its long-term sustainability strategy. Additionally, Aer Lingus has adopted a carbon offset program, allowing passengers to offset their emissions and contribute to sustainability projects.

As a member of the International Airlines Group (IAG), Aer Lingus is aligned with the group’s ambitious sustainability goals, which include achieving net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. Aer Lingus’ efforts in fleet modernization and its commitment to sustainable practices make it an important player in the push for sustainable aviation.

Wizz Air: Flying into the Future with Green Initiatives

Wizz Air, a Hungarian low-cost airline, has quickly become a major player in Europe’s aviation sector. The airline is committed to sustainability and has set an ambitious goal to reduce its CO2 emissions by 25% per passenger by 2030. Wizz Air has implemented a number of initiatives to meet this goal, including the use of the Airbus A321neo, one of the most fuel-efficient aircraft on the market.

The airline’s commitment to sustainability extends beyond its fleet, as it also works towards reducing waste and energy consumption in its operations. Wizz Air has also been exploring the use of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) and has been involved in projects that aim to reduce the carbon intensity of air travel.

Wizz Air’s focus on sustainability is not only environmentally driven but also economically beneficial. By investing in fuel-efficient aircraft and adopting green technologies, the airline reduces operating costs, which, in turn, allows it to offer more affordable flights to its passengers. This combination of sustainability and cost-effectiveness makes Wizz Air a key player in the low-cost, eco-friendly aviation market.

SAS: Committing to Net-Zero by 2050

SAS (Scandinavian Airlines) has made significant progress in reducing its carbon footprint. The airline has set a target to achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2050, with a focus on fleet modernization, fuel efficiency, and the development of alternative fuel technologies. SAS has been a leader in incorporating biofuels into its operations and is working to expand the use of SAF across its fleet.

SAS has also made investments in new, fuel-efficient aircraft like the Airbus A320neo and A350, which are expected to significantly reduce the airline’s emissions per flight. By focusing on reducing its environmental impact, SAS is not only improving its sustainability but also contributing to the wider industry’s efforts to address climate change.

SAS’s sustainability initiatives are also supported by its commitment to creating a more sustainable travel experience for passengers. The airline offers a range of carbon offset options, allowing passengers to contribute to sustainability projects.

United Airlines: Leading the Charge in SAF Adoption

United Airlines, based in the United States, is a global leader in the adoption of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF). The airline has committed to using SAF as a major part of its strategy to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. United has partnered with a number of SAF producers and has already begun using SAF on flights departing from its hub airports.

United Airlines has also been investing in fuel-efficient aircraft and technologies, such as its new fleet of Boeing 787 Dreamliners, which provide greater fuel efficiency and reduce emissions. The airline is also focused on improving its operational efficiency, from reducing weight on flights to optimizing flight routes for fuel savings.

Through its investments in SAF, fuel-efficient aircraft, and innovative technologies, United Airlines is making a significant contribution to the airline industry’s efforts to reduce its carbon footprint and combat climate change.

Air France: Advancing Sustainability with Innovation

Air France, one of the world’s leading international carriers, has been a pioneer in adopting sustainable practices in aviation. The airline has committed to achieving net-zero carbon emissions by 2050 and is focused on reducing its environmental impact through various initiatives, including fleet modernization, fuel efficiency, and the use of sustainable aviation fuel.

Air France has been investing in the Airbus A350, one of the most fuel-efficient long-haul aircraft, which reduces carbon emissions by up to 25% compared to older models. The airline has also committed to using SAF on flights and has partnered with several SAF suppliers to increase its usage across its fleet. In addition, Air France is actively involved in research and development efforts to advance green technologies and improve the sustainability of aviation.

Air France’s efforts to promote sustainability go beyond fleet management. The airline has implemented waste reduction initiatives, including eliminating plastic straws and single-use plastics from its flights. These actions demonstrate Air France’s commitment to sustainability and its role in leading the industry toward a greener future.

British Airways: Striving for Net-Zero Emissions

British Airways, the flagship carrier of the United Kingdom, has set an ambitious goal to achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. The airline is focusing on sustainable aviation fuel, fleet modernization, and carbon offset programs to meet its targets. British Airways is already using SAF on some of its flights and is working with several partners to increase its SAF usage.

In addition to using SAF, British Airways has been investing in newer, more fuel-efficient aircraft such as the Airbus A350 and Boeing 787, which contribute to reducing carbon emissions per passenger. The airline is also working on improving operational efficiency, such as optimizing flight routes and reducing weight on aircraft to lower fuel consumption.

British Airways’ commitment to sustainability is reflected in its efforts to not only reduce its environmental impact but also to promote sustainable tourism by offering passengers the option to offset their carbon emissions through the airline’s carbon offset program.

Ryanair, EasyJet, Aer Lingus, Wizz Air, SAS, United Airlines, Air France, and British Airways are all playing critical roles in boosting the airline industry’s commitment to sustainability. Through a combination of fleet modernization, the adoption of sustainable aviation fuel, carbon offset programs, and other innovative technologies, these airlines are making significant strides toward reducing their carbon footprints.

As sustainability becomes an increasingly important factor for both consumers and regulators, these airlines are setting a benchmark for the rest of the industry. Their efforts not only contribute to the global fight against climate change but also demonstrate that sustainability and profitability can go hand in hand. Moving forward, the airline industry will continue to rely on the innovations and leadership of these carriers to pave the way toward a more sustainable future.

Impact of New Authorization Systems on Tourism

The European Union is set to introduce the Entry/Exit System (EES) in October 2025, a new electronic system designed to monitor the border crossings of non-EU nationals. This system will replace traditional passport stamps with biometric data, including fingerprints and facial images, collected at the border entry points. The EES is being implemented to enhance border security and improve the efficiency of immigration processes. By automating border control procedures, the system is expected to reduce waiting times and improve the overall passenger experience for non-EU travelers, such as those from the United States and Asia.

For the tourism industry, the introduction of the EES is likely to have significant implications, particularly for travelers who frequently visit the EU. While the system aims to streamline entry procedures and enhance security, there are concerns that it may lead to longer processing times and additional bureaucratic hurdles for travelers, especially those who are not accustomed to biometric data collection. It will also raise questions about data privacy and the security of personal information. Despite these concerns, the system is expected to make border control more efficient, enabling travelers to cross into the EU more quickly and safely. For tourism operators, this may mean smoother operations, but they will also need to educate travelers on the new requirements to ensure a seamless travel experience. In the long term, the EES is expected to become a critical part of Europe’s border management strategy, impacting the flow of international visitors.

Shifts in European Travel Preferences

Recent data reveals a notable decline in the number of European tourists visiting the United States, with forward bookings for the summer 2025 season down by 25%. This trend can be attributed to several factors, including perceived travel restrictions, concerns over security at U.S. airports, and reports of detentions and lengthy border processes. As a result, travelers from Europe are increasingly opting for alternative destinations that are perceived to offer more seamless entry experiences and lower risks. Countries like Canada, South America, and Egypt are becoming increasingly popular for European tourists looking for new and exciting travel experiences.

The decline in European travel to the U.S. is a significant development for both tourism operators in Europe and their counterparts in the U.S. The drop in arrivals is also attributed to the complex visa application process and the perception that the U.S. has become less welcoming to international visitors. In contrast, destinations such as Canada, with its relaxed travel policies and welcoming reputation, are benefiting from this shift. Similarly, South America and Egypt have experienced a surge in European visitors due to their rich cultural offerings, lower travel costs, and growing accessibility. For European tourism professionals, this shift signals the need to adapt to changing consumer preferences and re-focus marketing efforts on promoting destinations that align with current traveler expectations. As this trend continues, it will reshape the tourism dynamics both in the U.S. and globally, with a growing emphasis on more accessible and culturally rich destinations.

The European travel industry is undergoing significant transformations as it navigates the complex interplay of policy reforms, technological advancements, and evolving consumer preferences. Stakeholders in the travel and transportation sectors, including airlines, high-speed rail companies, and tourism operators, must remain agile to respond to these changes effectively. The rise of new border control measures like the ETA and the EES, along with the increasing competition in the high-speed rail sector, will require both businesses and travelers to adapt quickly. Meanwhile, shifting travel preferences and an increased focus on sustainability will continue to shape the future of European tourism. To stay competitive in this rapidly changing environment, industry players must innovate, enhance customer experiences, and find ways to align with the growing demand for more efficient, secure, and eco-friendly travel options.

text:
International Airlines Group (IAG) is urging the UK government to accelerate its plans for a ‘revenue certainty mechanism’ (RCM) to support the production of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF), warning that delays could jeopardise the country’s aviation decarbonisation goals.

“To give the private sector confidence to invest, the UK government is introducing a ‘revenue certainty mechanism’ for SAF. This is a way to guarantee future SAF prices that derisks investment – similar to the model already successfully used to build the UK’s offshore wind industry,” said Jonathon Counsell, IAG’s Group Sustainability Officer.

“Price certainty gives investors confidence, and signals to international partners that the UK is an attractive place to build low carbon technologies.”

While welcoming the initiative, he stressed the need for further cost modelling and careful policy design. “We believe a revenue certainty mechanism is the right instrument to incentivise efficiency, balance priorities and offer value for money, but the important part will be in the detailed design which IAG will continue to support,” Counsell added.

The SAF Mandate starts in 2025 at 2% of total UK jet fuel demand, increasing linearly to 10% in 2030 and then to 22% in 2040.

But IAG warns that significant investment is needed to meet this goal.

“Speed is a key factor. The Department for Transport is currently aiming to have the policy finalised by the end of 2026. Ideally, we want to move quicker as the UK government’s 10% SAF mandate for airlines will come into force in 2030,” Counsell said.

“To help meet this, we would need six or seven new SAF plants in the UK within the next five years. It’s a tight timescale and our suppliers need certainty, fast, if they are to start and finish construction on these advanced and complex facilities.”

title: How to Increase Sustainable Aviation Fuel Production - Climate Insider
description:
Though production of sustainable aviation fuels has increased substantially in the past three years – with a massive uptick in 2024 – the numbers are actually quite small when compared to overall global jet fuel production.
Current SAF production accounts for only 0.3% of total fuel production, according to the International Air Transport Association (AITA).
BCG Highlights Concerns Over Sustainable Aviation Fuel Production BCG claims that sustainable aviation fuel production is now faltering and even shrinking.
Sustainable aviation fuel production costs are still high, which discourages innovation and project development.
This doesn’t build a great case for investment in SAF.” To expand sustainable aviation fuel production, the industry needs long-term off-takes.
text:
Sustainable aviation fuels have a problem: they’re taking far too long to develop, according to a new report released by the Boston Consulting Group.

Though production of sustainable aviation fuels has increased substantially in the past three years – with a massive uptick in 2024 – the numbers are actually quite small when compared to overall global jet fuel production. Current SAF production accounts for only 0.3% of total fuel production, according to the International Air Transport Association (AITA).

BCG Highlights Concerns Over Sustainable Aviation Fuel Production

BCG claims that sustainable aviation fuel production is now faltering and even shrinking. The announcement of new project facilities declined by 50% from 2022 to 2023, triggered by higher energy and operating costs as well as economic uncertainty, BCG reports.

All this is putting 2030 aviation decarbonization goals at risk, they say.

Neither of the two types of sustainable aviation fuel is close to meeting targets, BCG said, though they did not specify which targets they were referencing for this assessment.

One type of fuel, Bio-SAF, is produced from natural oils or biomass, and costs less to produce and has quicker project delivery estimates. These fuels are expected to miss 2030 production targets by 30%, BCG said.

The second type of fuel, called e-SAF, is produced from a thermochemical process. This process is more expensive than Bio-SAF, with yet-to-mature technologies. Production of this type of fuel is expected to miss 2030 targets by 45%, BCG said.

Exacerbating these fuel-production shortfalls is the less-than-stellar state of project approvals: Fewer than 30% of SAF projects reach a final investment decision, BCG noted.

Production has also taken a hit from delayed policy action, BCG said. The report points to the EU postponing a decision on sustainable aviation fuel eligibility criteria on the ReFuelEU Aviation initiative, which in turn caused a delay in companies announcing new projects.

This has also caused inertia among the main players in the sector, namely airports and airlines.

“Only a small subset of players has shown active leadership [in developing SAF stocks], and this trend is unlikely to shift without significant incentives or mandates,” the report said.

Part of this stasis is driven by the lack of a clear business case for developing sustainable aviation fuels.

Sustainable aviation fuel production costs are still high, which discourages innovation and project development. This then results in high prices for produced SAF, because of their scarcity on the market.

The BCG report suggests carbon prices could spur production. This would not only increase demand for the fuel, but help airlines and aviation players meet sustainability targets, which in turn would create more opportunities for investment.

Industry Voices Support SAF Scale-Up – But Say Fossil Fuel Sector Must Step In

Haldane Dodd, who heads the pro-sustainability Air Transport Action Group from Geneva, supported the findings of the report, but urged fossil fuel producers to be more involved.

“The BCG analysis outlines he challenge in getting the nascent [SAF] industry off the ground,” he told Climate Insider.

“But I notice that it didn’t mention the role of traditional energy suppliers: the fossil fuel producers which have the financial resources, the expertise, and the distribution networks to really invest in SAF scale-up.”

He implored the aviation industry to see the development of the fuel beyond just an industry-specific lens.

“SAF should not be seen just as an aviation transition – it is an energy transition, and the traditional energy sector is not front and centre where it should be.”

He applauded airports, airlines, aerospace manufacturers and all companies operating in the sector for filling the gap left by the fossil fuel industry, but emphasized that these players should not have to go it alone.

For SkyNRG’s Tom Berg, who serves as Director of Policy and Sustainability, the BCG report “stirred up some discussion” among sector players.

When it comes to increasing production, some areas are doing much better than others, Berg said.

“In Europe, we have a very solid long-term investment framework built on SAF mandates” Berg said. “In the EU, SkyNRG has been every year producing a SAF market outlook since 2021, and we’re seeing announced capacities are increasing year on year on year.”

In the US, there’s no financial certainty for SAF development, he pointed out.

“The system [for supporting SAF production] is built on tax incentives, and these are pretty volatile from administration to administration,” Berg said. “The certainty on getting these tax incentives varies. This doesn’t build a great case for investment in SAF.”

To expand sustainable aviation fuel production, the industry needs long-term off-takes.

Mandates can help with this, he said. Any stable, regulatory market which creates a firm long-term demand to build a business case can help with SAF production, Berg said.

Sustainable Aviation Fuel Production Growth Through Consumer Demand

In addition to creating regulations to aid in SAF development, there needs to be ways to channel voluntary demand into spurring more production, Berg said.

“We have people willing to pay at the corporate level,” he said. These corporations are not able to buy batches of SAF, but they are willing to pay more for transport and then use these SAF-propelled flights for emissions-reduction certificates.

SkyNRG aggregates this demand for customers, and then links it to supply deals.

“These are novel, innovative frameworks that can help speed things up,” Berg said. “On their own, voluntary purchases cannot really trigger production. But if you aggregate, you can see real volume [in production].”

Consolidating consumer demand for sustainable aviation fuel use goes hand-in-hand with a solid regulatory regime, he noted.

Berg agrees that carbon pricing also has a role to play, he said.

“In regions where there’s already carbon pricing, like the EU, the best thing you can do is take revenues from the carbon pricing regime, and use that to fund the decarbonization in aviation,” Berg said.

“Earmarking these carbon pricing revenues means the [aviation] sector can pay for its own transition, and use these revenues to pay for SAF,” he said, noting measures need to be put in place to ensure all buyers are on the same playing field and first-movers aren’t economically penalized.

“Taking those carbon pricing revenues and putting it to good use, can actually do a lot,” he said.

title: SAF Registry Goes Live - IATA
description:
In releasing the SAF Registry to CADO for launch, we have put in place a critical platform for the benefit of all stakeholders.
About the SAF Registry The SAF Registry is a global system to record SAF transactions in a standardized and transparent way.
The SAF Registry is technology and feedstock neutral, favoring the emergence of diverse SAF production streams across the world.
Participation in the SAF Registry will be free until April 2027, after which it will be operated on a cost recovery basis.
CADO’s founding member is the International Air Transport Association (IATA) which provides ongoing technical and operational support for the SAF Registry.
text:
Geneva – The International Air Transport Association (IATA) has launched the Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) Registry with its release to the Civil Aviation Decarbonization Organization (CADO). The Registry, now live under CADO management, will enable a global market for SAF that will accelerate the transition to net zero emissions by 2050.

“Aviation’s decarbonization is a team effort. In releasing the SAF Registry to CADO for launch, we have put in place a critical platform for the benefit of all stakeholders. It ensures that all airlines in the world have access to SAF and that their SAF purchases can be claimed against any climate-related obligations in this domain. The Registry will record the environmental attributes of SAF purchases in an immutable way, safeguarding against double counting. Airlines, their corporate customers, fuel producers, regulatory bodies, and all related organizations will be able to record and account for their SAF transactions in a global market for SAF. While this is of fundamental importance and a historically momentous advance, it is but one step along the way to a mature, transparent, and liquid global SAF market. The Registry cannot produce miracles on its own, but without it, no miracles can be produced.

Further progress requires active policy support for the ramping-up of all renewable energy production, and for SAF within that production. Governments must reallocate their direct support given to fossil fuel producers in favor of renewable energy production. The precedent of the wind and solar energy markets is the example to follow, and this without any further delay,” said Marie Owens Thomsen, IATA’s Senior Vice President Sustainability and Chief Economist.

About the SAF Registry

The SAF Registry is a global system to record SAF transactions in a standardized and transparent way. It ensures that the environmental benefits of SAF can be tracked as they move across the SAF value chain and enable the claiming of these against regulatory obligations and voluntary schemes by airlines and corporate customers.

The Registry helps solve the challenge of limited SAF supply —which is acutely scarce and available in only a few locations globally —by connecting airlines with SAF producers and suppliers, regardless of their geographical location. In addition, it gives airlines’ corporate customers access to in-sector emissions reductions and capitalizes on firms’ capacity to co-finance the cost of decarbonization.

The SAF Registry is technology and feedstock neutral, favoring the emergence of diverse SAF production streams across the world. It will be able to accommodate specific regulations, while favoring global harmonization. Moreover, interoperability with other registries is an important feature of the Registry, supporting competition and open markets.

The Registry was developed in consultation with airlines, government authorities, OEMs, fuel producers and suppliers, and corporate travel management companies. With over 30 early users (see appendix) already in the process of onboarding and ready to use the system, the Registry is underpinned by the IATA SAF Accounting and Reporting Methodology which provides a consistent approach to accounting for the environmental benefits of SAF purchases, regardless of location.

Participation in the SAF Registry will be free until April 2027, after which it will be operated on a cost recovery basis.

About CADO

The Civil Aviation Decarbonization Organization (CADO) was created in March 2025 to maintain and operate the IATA-developed SAF Registry. It is a not-for-profit organization established under Canadian Law with its headquarters in Montreal.

CADO’s founding member is the International Air Transport Association (IATA) which provides ongoing technical and operational support for the SAF Registry. Membership in CADO is open to international organizations and companies in the SAF value chain.

title: Can Algae-Based Fuel Make the Aviation Industry Greener? - DirectIndustry e-Magazine

text:
Conventional fuels used in the aviation industry harm the environment. A recent EU regulation pushes for greener alternatives to conventional fuels to meet the neutrality goals set for 2050. However, sustainable aviation fuels (SAFs) are costly, and Europe has limited production capacity for them. The European aviation industry must find a way to adopt these fuels cost-effectively, such as producing microalgae-based aviation fuels to make flying more environmentally friendly.

In the EU, civil aviation contributes over 13% of total CO2 emissions from transport, making it one of the sector’s largest sources of greenhouse gas emissions. One way to make the aviation industry more sustainable is by relying on sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) instead of conventional aviation fuel. This could lead to a reduction in CO2 emissions by as much as 80%.

In 2023, the European Parliament approved the ReFuelEU Aviation regulation, which aims to increase the use of SAF in line with the EU’s climate neutrality targets. According to the new rules, starting in 2025, a minimum of 2% of aviation fuels must be sustainable; this percentage will rise every five years, reaching 70% by 2050.

What is Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF)?

SAF is a cleaner alternative to traditional aviation fuel, derived from plant or animal materials instead of fossil fuels. Various sources can be used to produce SAF, including cooking oil, animal waste fat, agricultural and forestry waste, and even algae. It is designed to be nearly identical to conventional fuel, which allows it to be used in existing planes. For now SAF still needs to be mixed with traditional aviation fuel, but there are hopes that airlines will be able to use 100% SAF by 2030.

The challenge is that SAF prices can be up to 10 times higher than conventional fuel, although they are expected to decrease significantly with new production technologies.

Ronald Halim, professor at the School of Biosystems and Food Engineering at University College Dublin and project coordinator of the SusAlgaeFuel Project, says that relying on food waste limits SAF supply.

“The main source of sustainable aviation fuel at the moment is crops that have food uses and require agricultural land for cultivation. These are second-generation crops, meaning they are generally waste products from other systems or processes, such as used cooking oil. These sources are either unsustainable or have limited availability. There is a need for an alternative approach to produce sustainable aviation fuel, and that’s where microalgae can potentially come in.”

READ ALSO

What are the advantages and possible challenges of using algae-based fuels?

Algae-based fuel is gaining popularity in aviation due to its ability to grow in saltwater or wastewater, absorb CO2 from the atmosphere, and produce oil with minimal land uses , which means it doesn’t affect food production. The European algae biofuel market is expected to expand to $1.97 billion by 2033 at an annual growth rate of 6.89%.

“Algae offers several benefits for fuel production. Firstly, they are very oil-rich, meaning they contain significantly more oil per gram compared to oil-rich crops like oil palm or canola. Secondly, they grow rapidly, allowing for a quicker turnover time than conventional crops. For instance, traditional crops may require up to a year before harvesting for oil production, while microalgae can be harvested every 1 to 2 weeks, enabling a shorter growth cycle. This could lead to increased production,” said Professor Halim.

One of the main obstacles to transitioning to algae biofuels is the high cost of converting microalgae lipids into aviation fuel. Algae require nutrients, a specific temperature, and water to grow. Once the algae biomass is obtained, processing it demands a significant amount of energy.

Professor Halim’s SusAlgaeFuel Project is developing approaches to lower the cost of growing and processing algae. This can make the resulting algae fuel cost-competitive with other types of sustainable aviation fuels, and make it available for local production in the EU.

Working towards a cost-effective and sustainable solution

The SusAlgaeFuel project brings together technology providers specializing in microalgal cultivation and AI-driven sensor technology, along with experts in biomass processing and aviation fuel synthesis from five European countries, all collaborating to make the aviation industry more environmentally friendly.

Their approach involves cultivating algae using wastewater from the anaerobic digestion sector rather than relying on expensive clean water and nutrients. Using waste nutrients can lower the cost of algae production while simultaneously treating waste. This creates a win-win situation: The anaerobic digestion industry can convert its waste into valuable biomass, and the aviation sector benefits from lower sustainable fuel costs.

“I sincerely hope we can generate innovative science that is beneficial to scientists and industries worldwide. I want our results to serve industry stakeholders and potentially be translated into commercial applications, perhaps not during the project but shortly after its completion. This way, we can have an impact beyond just scientific publications; we can influence actual commercialisation in the aviation and anaerobic digestion sectors in Ireland and the EU,” said Professor Halim.

title: The Expansion of Sustainable Fuel in Private Aviation - VURDHAAN
description:
A Milestone for European Terminals In a notable step toward reshaping the carbon footprint of private aviation, six prominent European airports are preparing to introduce blended sustainable aviation fuel starting in 2025.
Each location selected plays a strategic role in private aviation, and expanding fuel access here allows for a broader shift in operational patterns and customer expectations.
The Infrastructure Behind the Commitment Behind this initiative is one of the most robust sustainable fuel supply chains currently operating in aviation.
Agreements signed with major suppliers will contribute over fifty million gallons of sustainable fuel to be distributed throughout 2025.
Bridging Sustainability with Everyday Operations A sustainable fuel option is not simply a sustainability win—it is an operational one too.
text:
A Milestone for European Terminals

In a notable step toward reshaping the carbon footprint of private aviation, six prominent European airports are preparing to introduce blended sustainable aviation fuel starting in 2025. This includes major hubs like Heathrow, Gatwick, Luton, Paris Le Bourget, East Midlands, and Manchester. These additions mark a growing trend of integrating sustainability deeper into aviation infrastructure and service delivery.

The inclusion of these airports raises the number of locations across Europe, the Middle East, and Africa offering sustainable fuels to eight, and brings the total global count to thirty-three. It is a testament to growing momentum and operational readiness in transitioning to cleaner fuels across regions with high traffic volumes.

From Announcement to Impact

While the announcement itself might appear as just another milestone in corporate sustainability communications, its implications run deeper. These airports are not merely adding a product option; they are becoming catalysts of industry change. By facilitating access to cleaner fuel alternatives, they support operators in meeting regulatory requirements and voluntary climate goals more easily.

Each location selected plays a strategic role in private aviation, and expanding fuel access here allows for a broader shift in operational patterns and customer expectations.

The Infrastructure Behind the Commitment

Behind this initiative is one of the most robust sustainable fuel supply chains currently operating in aviation. Agreements signed with major suppliers will contribute over fifty million gallons of sustainable fuel to be distributed throughout 2025. This commitment reflects the growing confidence in both availability and distribution reliability—two critical factors that have historically hindered SAF adoption.

This level of supply coordination helps overcome one of the industry’s silent challenges: inconsistency in availability. By ensuring steady volumes across high-demand locations, these supply agreements aim to normalize the use of SAF rather than treat it as a premium or exclusive option.

Bridging Sustainability with Everyday Operations

A sustainable fuel option is not simply a sustainability win—it is an operational one too. It means aircraft operators can integrate sustainability into their routine without having to drastically alter routes, logistics, or fuel sourcing mechanisms. And when sustainability aligns with operational efficiency, adoption accelerates naturally.

For private aviation, which often faces scrutiny for its outsized emissions relative to passenger count, such steps provide a tangible path to offset environmental concerns without compromising service levels or flexibility.

The Road Ahead in 2025

The announcement hints at a cascade of developments planned for 2025, particularly within the Europe and Middle East region. One such advancement is the upcoming introduction of a fully electric refueler at the Nice airport, a symbolic and practical move that reflects how ground services are evolving to match decarbonisation narratives.

This signals that sustainability in aviation is no longer confined to the skies. Ground handling and refueling infrastructure are now being designed to ensure that carbon reduction efforts are integrated across the value chain.

Quiet Leadership Through Measurable Action

The organization driving these expansions has already achieved a significant milestone—crossing the threshold of fifty million gallons of sustainable fuel pumped. Recognition from the United States Environmental Protection Agency, in the form of a Green Power Leadership Award, underscores the alignment between their efforts and broader environmental goals.

These actions collectively reflect a model of quiet leadership—less about grand statements, and more about infrastructural change and measurable emissions reductions.

Conclusion: A Blueprint for Future-Focused Aviation

This expansion is not just about making fuel available. It is about embedding sustainability into the very fabric of aviation services. It serves as a positive reminder that impactful progress often comes from logistical clarity, infrastructure readiness, and long-term supplier alignment.

By strengthening access to cleaner fuels at key locations, this initiative offers a blueprint for other regions and operators who wish to decarbonize effectively. The shift is no longer theoretical—it is quietly, steadily becoming a daily reality in aviation’s operational flow.

title: How Are Airlines Trying To Reduce Their Carbon Footprint? - Travel Radar - Aviation News
description:
Reducing carbon footprint has been all the rage for many industries as the threat of continued global warming ensues.
Fully electric planes have a much lower carbon footprint especially if renewable sources are used to produce electricity.
Offsets, Carbon Capture, And Operational Efficiencies Offsets and carbon capture alone have the potential to reduce the aviation industry’s carbon footprint by 19%.
In addition, using lighter cabin equipment and automated systems to improve efficiency can also reduce fuel consumption and therefore improve the industry’s carbon footprint.
To conclude, therefore, there are a number of improvements that are taking place in the industry as a whole to reduce carbon emissions and the industry’s carbon footprint.
text:
Reducing carbon footprint has been all the rage for many industries as the threat of continued global warming ensues. There have been calls for all industries to lower their carbon dioxide emissions (termed as their carbon footprint) in order to lower the global rise in temperature resulting in abnormal weather patterns around the world. As one can see therefore, there is a powerful impetus for change.

The aviation industry has responded to this.

At the International Air Transport Association (IATA) 77th Annual General Meeting in Boston in the United States on the 4th October 2021, a resolution was passed by IATA member airlines committing them to achieving net zero carbon emissions by 2050. This is a considerable commitment by an organisation representing 80% of the world’s airlines. There are a number of areas the IATA is targeting in order to meet this objective.

SAF

According to the IATA, it is estimated that 65% of the reduction in the industry’s carbon footprint centre around SAF (Sustainable Aviation Fuel). SAF is a plant based fuel which produces 80% less carbon emissions when compared to traditional jet fuel. This fuel is made from a variety of plant-based sources including agricultural waste, waste oils and fats, as well as forestry residues and non food crops. It is considered sustainable as it does not compete with land needed for growing crops and does not result in deforestation or loss of biodiversity in clearing land for cultivation.

So far more than 40 countries around the world have announced SAF projects. Many airlines already use SAF such as Virgin Atlantic, British Airways and Turkish Airlines. In 2024, 1.25 billion litres of SAF were produced. However in order for SAF to help meet the target of net zero by 2050, there has to be a massive increase in production. Nevertheless, the IATA feels that it is possible to replace almost all jet fuel with SAF by 2050.

New Technology, electric and hydrogen

13% of the reduction in carbon footprint is estimated to be achievable through the use of New Technology. In particular, the creation of hybrid electric and purely electric planes will help. Hybrid-electric planes, where an electric system works in conjunction with a traditional combustion engine, greatly reduces carbon emissions. The combustion engine only works in conjunction with the electric system during take off and the electric system takes over afterwards. Combustion engines would also be of lower weight, reducing overall fuel consumption. Whilst this is not ideal as traditional fuel is still needed, the production of hybrid planes paves the way for the production of electric planes. Fully electric planes have a much lower carbon footprint especially if renewable sources are used to produce electricity. At the moment, however, the batteries which power electric planes are far heavier than the equivalent fuel for traditional aircraft.

Hydrogen is a carbon free fuel and can operate with traditional combustion engines or as part of electric batteries. It is also three times lighter than traditional jet fuel but has 4 times the volume, which would necessitate fundamental changes in the fuel systems of aircraft. Nevertheless, hydrogen powered planes as well as hybrid and pure electric planes, have the potential to enter service in the 2030’s. There are also developments in making planes more aerodynamic which reduces wind resistance thereby reducing fuel consumption.

Offsets, Carbon Capture, And Operational Efficiencies

Offsets and carbon capture alone have the potential to reduce the aviation industry’s carbon footprint by 19%. Offsetting involves forest conservation and rehabilitation of peat lands which help absorb carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. Carbon capture involves using large fans to filter through air using a chemical absorbent to absorb carbon dioxide which can then be stored and used for the production of Sustainable Aviation Fuel.

Operational and Infrastructure improvements account for 3% of the potential reduction in carbon footprint for the aviation industry. These improvements include, for example, reducing delays at airports so that planes spend less fuel taxiing (which is essentially moving on route between the airport and runway). In addition, using lighter cabin equipment and automated systems to improve efficiency can also reduce fuel consumption and therefore improve the industry’s carbon footprint.

To conclude, therefore, there are a number of improvements that are taking place in the industry as a whole to reduce carbon emissions and the industry’s carbon footprint. We hope that the IATA’s efforts to reduce carbon emissions to net zero emissions by 2050 are realised but we will have to wait to see how this progresses.

title: Tidewater Renewables reports fire incident at its renewable diesel refinery
description:
Tidewater Renewables Ltd. reports that, at approximately 9:00 a.m. (MST) on April 1, 2025, there was a minor fire (the "Incident") in the main renewable diesel process unit at the corporation's renewable diesel refinery (the "HDRD complex") located in Prince George, British Columbia.
The Incident has been extinguished and the impacted area of the HDRD complex has been isolated and stabilized.
While the investigation is in its early stages, Tidewater Renewables is encouraged by the seemingly low level of damage resulting from the Incident.
Given the product inventory levels maintained at the HDRD complex, the outage is not expected to have a material impact on Tidewater Renewables' operating and financial results (assuming the resumption of operations as expected).
Tidewater Renewables will provide more information as the investigation into the Incident progresses if any new information comes to light.
text:
Tidewater Renewables Ltd. reports that, at approximately 9:00 a.m. (MST) on April 1, 2025, there was a minor fire (the "Incident") in the main renewable diesel process unit at the corporation's renewable diesel refinery (the "HDRD complex") located in Prince George, British Columbia.

The Incident has been extinguished and the impacted area of the HDRD complex has been isolated and stabilized. The corporation confirms that all personnel are accounted for and no injuries have been reported at this time.

The corporation continues to investigate the Incident, both on its own behalf and in cooperation with the applicable regulatory authorities. While the investigation is in its early stages, Tidewater Renewables is encouraged by the seemingly low level of damage resulting from the Incident.

The corporation maintains a full suite of spare parts at the HDRD complex and should be in a position to rectify the damage and complete the appropriate testing and analysis required to safely bring the HDRD complex back online in short order. Given the product inventory levels maintained at the HDRD complex, the outage is not expected to have a material impact on Tidewater Renewables' operating and financial results (assuming the resumption of operations as expected). Tidewater Renewables will provide more information as the investigation into the Incident progresses if any new information comes to light.

title: Vibra delivers SAF at Rio airport | Biofuels International Magazine
description:
Fuel distributor Vibra has begun offering sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) in Brazil.
The imported biofuel is now available at its facility at Tom Jobim International Airport (GIG) in Rio de Janeiro, making Vibra the first company to supply SAF in the country.
In January, a shipment of 23 iso-tank containers carrying about 550,000 litres of SAF departed from the Port of Antwerp in Belgium for Rio de Janeiro.
The SAF supplied by Vibra is produced from used cooking oil (UCO), one of the most sustainable feedstocks due to its low carbon intensity.
“We are ready to expand SAF availability in Brazil, leveraging our infrastructure in over 90 airports and our expertise in delivering safe and competitive solutions,” said Marcelo Bragança, Vibra’s chief operating officer.

text:
Varo Energy, a European energy company based in Switzerland, on March 31 announced an agreement to acquire Preem, a Sweden-based petroleum and biofuels company that is developing additional renewable diesel and sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) capacity.

Under the agreement, Varo will acquire Preem Holding AB and Preem AB via the purchase of 100% of the share capital of the parent company, Corral Petroleum Holdings AB, in an all-cash transaction. The acquisition is subject to customary closing conditions and regulatory approvals and is currently expected to close during the second half of 2025.

The transaction includes Preem’s refineries in Lysekil and Gothenburg, Sweden, as well as the company’s storage infrastructure and fuel station network. Preem in late 2023 announced plans to move forward with a conversion project at the Lysekil refinery to produce renewable diesel and SAF. The company also produces renewable diesel at the Gothenburg refinery.

According to Varo, Preem was an early mover in renewable fuel production, investing nearly $1 billion since 2010 in initiatives to produce renewable fuels and reduce carbon intensity throughout the value chain. The company currently has the capacity to produce 300,000 metric tons per year of renewable fuels. Varo estimates renewables capacity will increase to 1.3 million metric tons per year once upgrades are complete at the Lysekil refinery.

text:
Charoen Pokphand Foods Public Company Limited (CP Foods) has joined forces with Bangchak Corporation to transform used cooking oil from its quick-service restaurant (QSR) operations—such as Five Star and Chester’s—into Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF). This initiative aligns with the company’s commitment to waste-to-value innovations, including alternative energy solutions.

Following the launch of its collaboration with Bangchak in 2024, CP Foods is now expanding the program by partnering with the Ministry of Industry and key private sector players to establish a supply chain network for used cooking oil. This effort supports Thailand’s ambition to achieve net-zero emissions.

CP Foods and its partners, including Bangchak, have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with the Ministry of Industry through the Department of Industrial Promotion. The agreement aims to accelerate SAF production, promote clean energy, and reduce the aviation sector’s environmental impact.

Kobboon Srichai, Head of Corporate Affairs & Investor Relations at CP Foods, emphasized the significance of the initiative. “Our partnership with Bangchak in 2024 was a major step forward. Today’s collaboration further strengthens our commitment to maximizing resource efficiency while setting new sustainability benchmarks for Thailand’s food industry.”

She added, “This initiative reflects our dedication to ‘Sustainovation’—integrating sustainability with innovation to ensure food security and create products that benefit both people and the planet.”

Anarkawee Chooratn, Head of Marketing at CP Foods, highlighted the company’s strict food safety measures. “We limit oil usage to just two rounds in our production process to uphold the highest food safety standards. This not only enhances food quality but also generates a steady supply of used cooking oil, which can be repurposed into clean energy like SAF—turning waste into value and benefiting the environment.”

Other MoU signatories include Central Group, Thai Beverage Public Company Limited, Thai President Foods Public Company Limited, and the Thai Food Processors’ Association, all of whom are committed to advancing sustainable solutions for a greener future.

Tim Walz wants to lower the state’s sales tax rate by 0.075%.

text:
Industrial officials have joined hands with businesses to support a project to convert used cooking oil into sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), in a bid to reduce carbon dioxide emissions.

The aviation industry is promoting SAF because this type of biofuel for aircraft produces up to 80% fewer greenhouse gas emissions than conventional jet fuel, according to media reports citing various forecasts.

"We aim to produce a new industry that is kind to the environment to help Thailand achieve carbon neutrality," said Industry Minister Akanat Promphan.

Former premier Prayut Chan-o-cha announced in 2021 at the 26th UN Climate Change Conference that Thailand would be more aggressive in addressing climate change, striving to reach carbon neutrality, a balance between carbon dioxide emissions and absorption, by 2050.

Mr Akanat was speaking during a memorandum of understanding (MoU) signing ceremony between the Department of Industrial Promotion (DIPROM), energy conglomerate Bangchak Corporation Plc, four large companies that use cooking oil in their food businesses -- Central Group, Thai Beverage, Charoen Pokphand Foods and Thai President Foods -- as well as the Thai Food Processors Association.

Authorities are analysing the volume of SAF demand and its supply, which can be derived from a variety of sources, including palm oil and molasses from sugar cane, said Natthiya Netayasubha, chief of DIPROM.

Under the MoU, the department and the companies will work on supply chain management to ensure they can gather sufficient amounts of used cooking oil to produce SAF.

Another prong covers public education on the benefits of used cooking oil in helping to cut carbon dioxide emissions.

The government should promote the use of various raw materials to make SAF and come up with a mandate that clearly sets out how much SAF is needed for the Thai aviation industry, said Chaiwat Kovavisarach, president of Bangchak Corp.

The company said earlier that its construction of an SAF factory, with a daily production capacity of 1 million litres near Bangchak's oil refinery in Phra Khanong district, was 93% complete.

The facility uses used cooking oil as a raw material.

On approach to environmental targets in the aviation sector in 2025

Lauren Riley: There is no lack of change here in the United States, but it’s not just in the United States, it’s also in other regions around the world like the EU and the UK and elsewhere. They’re looking at adding different policies that address sustainability in aviation. Change is happening everywhere. Fundamental to United commitment to net zero by 2050 is that it’s anchored in our business strategy today.

Fuel is our number two operational cost right behind labor and we don’t hedge on fuel purchase…what’s interesting about sustainable aviation fuel and why we’re also anchored in investing in this space is that it gives us line of sight to be able to stabilize the cost of a very volatile cost to United’s operation…*

We do want to drive the emissions out of our supply chain. When we made our commitment to net zero a couple of years ago, we did it without relying on the use of carbon offsets. And really that was our declaration from a somewhat principled point of view that we have to focus on permanent reductions and that’s why we’re so bullish about sustainable aviation fuels...

Robert Horton: We’ve intentionally engineered externalities out of the equation. Last year we [Dallas Fort Worth International Airport] celebrated 50 years as an airport. That’s a few changes of administration, but the way that we frame environmental or sustainable goals is that it is the right thing to do. It is also good from a business perspective.

For example, if we look at the last 15 – 20 years, we’ve reduced our energy costs by almost 40% and our annual spending on energy by almost 40%. And that’s significant because as you reduce or engineer the waste out of your systems, you’re also reducing your environmental footprint.

The sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) conversation is a lot more challenging for us as an airport because airports don’t really purchase fuel. That’s mainly the airlines or consortiums, but we are intentional about supporting or enabling that. For example, we’ve done a lot of pilots with used cooking oil, collecting that, and then routing that to recyclers to refine and convert it into sustainable fuels…

On affordability and accessibility of SAF

Charlotte Lollar: Sustainable aviation fuel is very expensive. It’s also very necessary. When you ask a question about whose responsibility it is, it’s kind of the responsibility [of all of us]. There are a lot of players in this value chain and it’s a shared risk model. There is a premium associated with it. There is a necessary step change that has to happen in the technology in order to scale and make it more affordable.

I think we often have conversations about parity and we’re really kind of focused on the end costs and really it’s about affordability, but it’s also economies of scale and getting the tech there. And so it’s kind of a shared responsibility…

Adam Klauber: As a business, we have to sell where we get the highest price, however it makes most sense to reduce the logistics costs that’s associated. There are emissions there too. Even pipelines have emissions. Can we deliver to the closest, the nearest airport to our production capacity? That is really what makes sense.

In terms of another way for us to address some of the price premium is to be transparent with pricing. Our model is to have what we call a cost plus or contract for differences model where we have all the incentives stacked and we show our customers what they are, and we think that this is an important way to get buy-in. The customers understand there’s a fixed margin, but all the rest can fluctuate according to market conditions. They understand the market conditions.
